Expectation1: Conduct experiments to test hypotheses and gather data
Situation1: The experiment is reserved during a limited window when specialized instruments are available.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: They are expected at routine meetings that occur frequently
Story: I stared at the lab schedule, my name highlighted in yellow for the only available slot with the mass spectrometer this month. Weeks of preparation had led to this moment; the samples were ready, and the hypotheses I’d crafted needed data to stand or fall. But as I set up the first run, my phone buzzed—a reminder for the advocacy meeting downtown. It was routine, but my presence was expected, my voice needed to support the community’s case in court. I could almost hear my colleagues’ disappointment if I missed the experiment, and I could picture the advocates’ faces if I failed to show up, letting down those who counted on me. The minutes ticked by, each one tightening the knot in my stomach. I weighed the irreplaceable data against the cause I’d sworn to champion, feeling the pressure of two worlds pulling me apart.
